conclusion: The Stirling cycle involves transitions between states A, B, C, and D, returning to A.
Processes A→B and C→D are isothermal.
In the P-V diagram, process C→D shows pressure increasing while volume decreasing.
The number of molecules colliding with unit area of wall per unit time (collision rate) is proportional to number density and square root of temperature.
The number density is given by n/V, where n is the number of molecules and V is the volume.
The proportionality includes constants and average molecular speed.
Temperature remains constant during the C→D process.
Average molecular speed remains constant during the C→D process.

premise: Volume decreases from C to D.

conclusion: The number of molecules (n) remains constant throughout the cycle.

premise: Volume decreases and n is constant.
conclusion: Number density increases from C to D: n/V_D > n/V_C

premise: Collision rate is proportional to number density at constant temperature.
conclusion: Collision rate at D > Collision rate at C
In an isothermal process, T is constant.

premise: P_C * V_C = nRT and P_D * V_D = nRT
Collision rate ∝ n/V at constant T
conclusion: Collision rate at C ∝ 1/V_C and at D ∝ 1/V_D

premise: During the isothermal process C→D, volume decreases while maintaining constant temperature.
conclusion: The number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time increases.
